title: 111_s591
content:
The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission with specific purposes, composition, duties, powers, and staff provisions. It also includes sections on compensation, security clearances, reports, and termination. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel, known as the "Commission," is established by the National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 for specific purposes. The Commission is tasked with evaluating potential improvements in the US approach to high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel management if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. They will submit a report to Congress with their findings and recommendations to enhance the country's waste management strategies. The Commission will provide conclusions and recommendations to enhance the management of defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, high-level waste, and commercial radioactive waste in the United States. SEC. 4. COMPOSITION. The Commission shall consist of 9 members meeting specific qualifications, with 2 appointed by the majority leader of the Senate, 2 by the minority leader of the Senate, and 2 by the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Commission consists of 9 members with specific qualifications. 2 members are appointed by the majority leader of the Senate, 2 by the minority leader of the Senate, 2 by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, 2 by the minority leader of the House of Representatives, and 1 jointly by the majority leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Individuals appointed to the Commission must not be engaged in high-level radioactive waste activities with the Department of Energy or be officers or employees of the Federal Government, Indian tribe, State, or local government. The Commission members must be prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields, appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The appointed individual under subsection (a)(5) will serve as the Chairperson. The Commission will begin operations promptly after the Act's enactment and will meet as needed, with a quorum of five members required. The Commission will meet when called by the Chairperson or a majority of members. A quorum of five members is needed for meetings. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for managing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including transferring responsibility to a Federal Government corporation with authority and funding for storage. Cost-sharing options with private industry and establishing centralized interim storage facilities are also being considered. The Commission is considering options for managing radioactive waste, including establishing centralized interim storage facilities in willing communities and researching advanced fuel cycle technologies to prevent weapons proliferation. The Commission is exploring options for radioactive waste management, including centralized interim storage facilities and advanced fuel cycle technologies. Legislation requires the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to dry casks at reactor sites for public safety and security. The Commission is considering options for radioactive waste management, including centralized interim storage facilities and advanced fuel cycle technologies. Legislation mandates the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to dry casks at reactor sites for public safety and security, followed by permanent geologic disposal and interim strategies for defense wastes. Additional management and technological approaches are also being explored. The Commission is exploring options for radioactive waste management, including centralized interim storage facilities and advanced fuel cycle technologies. They are considering improved security for spent nuclear fuel storage installations and consulting with various stakeholders. Recommendations on waste disposition will be submitted. The Commission will submit recommendations on the disposition of existing fees charged to nuclear energy ratepayers and analyze the financial impacts on the Federal Government's contractual liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. They will then submit a final report to Congress. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress as required by the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths. It can also enter into contracts to fulfill its duties and obtain information from federal agencies. The Commission under this Act can directly obtain information from federal agencies for its purposes. Each federal department or agency must provide information to the Commission in a timely manner as authorized by law. The Commission can request information from federal agencies and must handle and disseminate it in accordance with applicable laws. Assistance can be provided by federal agencies like the General Services Administration. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other federal agencies can also offer services, funds, facilities, staff, and support as requested and authorized by law. The Commission may request and use services, funds, facilities, staff, and support services as authorized by law. Additionally, the Commission can utilize the United States mails like other federal agencies. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and staff can be utilized as authorized by law. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint staff without following certain federal employment regulations, as outlined in the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The staff director and personnel of the Commission are federal employees under specific sections of title 5, United States Code. The Commission may detail Federal Government employees without reimbursement and procure consultant services in accordance with title 5. Members of the Commission are exempt from this provision. The Commission may procure consultant services from experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the daily rate paid to a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule under title 5. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION; TRAVEL EXPENSES. The Commission may procure consultant services from experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the daily rate paid to a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule under title 5. Each member of the Commission may be compensated at a daily rate not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided for members while away from their home or regular place of business. Expenses, including per diem, are allowed for Commission members similar to intermittent Government employees under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. The Federal agencies will assist the Commission in obtaining security clearances for its members and staff. No access to classified information will be granted without appropriate clearances. SEC. 11. REPORTS. The Commission will release an interim report for public comment within 1 year of the Act's enactment, and a final report to Congress within 2 years of its first meeting, containing findings, conclusions, recommendations, and individual opinions of the members. The final report must be approved by a majority of the Commission members, include opinions of dissenting members with explanations, and consider public comments. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out this Act.

SEC. 13. TERMINATION. The Commission's authority ends 180 days after the final report submission. During this period, the Commission can conclude its activities, provide testimony to Congress, and disseminate the final report.
